Arkeolog Temukan Tembok Kuno 115 Km di Iran, Siapa yang Bangun?
07 Nov 2019, 00:09 by Moh Khory Alfarizi, Yudono Yanuar
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Arkeolog telah mengidentifikasi sisa-sisa tembok batu di Iran sepanjang sekitar 115 kilometer di Sar Pol-e Zahab, Iran barat.
"Dengan perkiraan volume batu 35 juta meter kubik, itu akan membutuhkan sumber daya yang signifikan dalam hal tenaga kerja, bahan, dan waktu," tulis Sajjad Alibaigi, mahasiswa doktoral di departemen arkeologi di Teheran University, dalam artikel yang diterbitkan di jurnal Antiquity.
Panjang tembok Iran ini hampir menyamai Tembok Hadrian yang dibangun di Inggris oleh orang Romawi. Panjang tembok Hadrian sampai 118 km.
Struktur tembok membentang dari utara-selatan dari Pegunungan Bamu di utara ke daerah dekat desa Zhaw Marg di selatan, demikian dikutip Live Science, baru-baru ini.
Keramik atau tembikar yang ditemukan di sepanjang dinding menunjukkan bahwa tembok dibangun antara abad keempat sebelum Masehi dan abad keenam Masehi.
"Sisa bangunan terlihat di tempat-tempat di sepanjang dinding. Ini mungkin berhubungan dengan menara atau bangunan," tulis Alibaigi. "Tembok itu terbuat dari bahan lokal alami, seperti jalan berbatu dan batu-batu besar, dengan mortar gipsum bertahan di beberapa tempat."
Meskipun keberadaan dinding baru diketahui oleh para arkeolog, mereka yang tinggal di dekatnya telah lama mengetahui tentang dinding itu, dan menyebutnya Dinding Gawri.
Para arkeolog tidak yakin siapa yang membangun struktur itu, dan untuk tujuan apa. Karena kelangkaan pelindung yang buruk, para ilmuwan bahkan tidak yakin dengan lebar dan tingginya yang tepat. Perkiraan terbaik mereka adalah lebar 4 meter dan tinggi sekitar 3 m.
Dalam catatan Alibaigi, tembok itu mungkin menandai perbatasan untuk kekaisaran kuno, Parthia (yang berkembang antara 247 SM dan 224 M) atau Sassania (224-651 M). Kedua kerajaan di Iran barat membangun istana besar, kota dan sistem irigasi, sehingga kemungkinan keduanya memiliki sumber daya untuk membangun Tembok Gawri.
LIVE SCIENCE | ANTIQUITY

Archaeologists Discover the Ancient Wall 115 Km in Iran, Who Woke Up?
Nov 7 2019, 00:09 by Moh Khory Alfarizi, Yudono Yanuar
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Archaeologists have identified remnants of a stone wall in Iran for about 115 kilometers in Sar Pol-e Zahab, western Iran.
"With an estimated stone volume of 35 million cubic meters, it will require significant resources in terms of labor, materials and time," wrote Sajjad Alibaigi, doctoral student in the archeology department at Tehran University, in an article published in the journal Antiquity.
The length of the Iranian wall is almost like the Hadrian's Wall which was built in England by the Romans. The length of Hadrian's wall is 118 km.
The wall structure stretches from north-south from the Bamu Mountains in the north to the area near the village of Zhaw Marg in the south, Live Science was quoted as saying recently.
Ceramics or pottery found along the walls show that the wall was built between the fourth century BC and the sixth century AD.
"The rest of the building is visible in places along the wall. This may be related to the tower or building," Alibaigi wrote. "The wall is made of natural local materials, such as rocky roads and large stones, with gypsum mortars enduring in several places."
Although the existence of a wall is only known to archaeologists, those who live nearby have long known about the wall, and call it the Gawri Wall.
Archaeologists are not sure who built the structure, and for what purpose. Because of the scarcity of poor protectors, scientists are not even sure of the exact width and height. Their best estimate is 4 meters wide and about 3 m high.
In Alibaigi's account, the wall may mark the boundary for the ancient empire, Parthia (which developed between 247 BC and 224 AD) or Sassania (224-651 AD). The two kingdoms in western Iran built large palaces, cities and irrigation systems, so it is possible that both of them had the resources to build the Gawri Wall.
